concept.label: Member of the European Parliament, 1989–1994
concept.definition: "Member of the European Parliament, 1989–1994" refers to an individual who served as an elected representative in the European Parliament, the legislative body of the European Union, during the term that ran from 1989 to 1994. This representative would have been responsible for making decisions on EU-wide legislation, budget and treaties during this five-year term. Their membership would have required winning an election in one of the member countries of the European Union.

data.rationale: Arturo Juan Escuder Croft fits the definition of a "Member of the European Parliament, 1989–1994" because he served as an elected representative in the European Parliament during the term that ran from 1989 to 1994. data.label: Jim Fitzsimons
data.description: Jim Fitzsimons, also known as James T. Fitzsimons and G.W.G. Fitzsimons, is a notable individual in Irish politics and academia. Born on December 16, 1936, in Navan, County Meath, Ireland, Fitzsimons is a member of the Fianna Fáil political party. He served in the Irish Parliament (Dáil) during the 21st, 22nd, 23rd, and 24th terms. He was also a Member of the European Parliament (MEP) representing the Republic of Ireland for several terms between 1984 and 2004. In addition to his political career, Fitzsimons is recognized for his academic contributions as a Master of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1988. He was also a Mayor of Manchester. He was educated at St Patrick's Classical School and his alma mater is Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge.
